questions.question_text: Users are reporting issues with slow connection speeds and a loss of connectivity on the newly installed wireless network. The issues are intermittent but seem to occur most often around midday. Which of the following is the MOST likely cause?

comments.content: Agree!
A is wrong. "Users" are reporting. I will agree if the report was coming from a single user. Absolutely C is the correct answer,
How HDCP related to slow connection speeds?

discussion.content:
The answer is:
A. There is interference from small appliances.
This is because at lunch (midday) the microwaves are being used at the 2.4GHz range. It has nothing to do with DHCP. They’re ‘losing’ connectivity, which indicates that they’ve already received a DHCP address.
Interference from Microwave (specifically mid-day lunch hour) that's the reason.

comments.content: you would be correct IF this happened other times during the day.

discussion.content: Did no one consider that a corrupted DNS cache directly effects connection speed? If there's a corrupt DNS server then all of the users would be making faulty inquires that are taking up more computing resources than normal

Selected Answer: A
It says through the day and midday...

Selected Answer: C
i really believe is C.

Everyone is assuming microwaves and baby monitors. The same is true for the assumption that midday is the time where DHCP leases get renewed, and it midday being the time where the office has the most visitors/guests who use the network (hence, running out of address), you can interpret the question in so many ways.
This network is newly installed. It can use 5 GHZ frequency instead 2.4 GHZ frequency.

if they wanted you to think of microwaves, or other devices causing interference, they would have hinted at the use of those types during lunch hour, but instead it just says "midday" which does encompass lunch hour, but can also mean a time window of 4 hours or so, and there is zero mention of there even being microwaves in the building, so to arrive at microwaves is making a HUGE assumption. Whereas, DHCP exhaustion during peak hours (aka "midday") is a very common thing and one that was hinted at when the question states "users losing connectivity" AND "users not able to connect". A microwave wouldn't cause BOTH of those issues. lack of DHCP addresses and network congestion would.

Here is what i don't get. Someone has a DCHP given address to have a connection to lose. If the lease runs out why wouldn't dhcp give the same address back. New users would not be able to connect due to no addresses, but not lose connectivity. Would an increase in DORA's cause slow connectivity?

comments.content:
An exhausted DHCP pool would also suggest a lot of users taking up bandwidth which would cause slow speeds. The exhausted DHCP pool would prevent others from accessing the network all together. 
How anyone is jumping directly to these outlandish microwave theories is ridiculous. The given answer is correct.

I agree that the answer is exhausted DHCP pool but calling the Microwave outlandish comes from a place of privilege, lol. You have no idea how many places I've been that have Microwaves with poor shielding that every time it's ran jams the Wi-Fi in the local area.

discussion.content: I can't see how too few DHCP addresses can cause slow connection speeds so the answer must be A. That's all that makes sense

comments.content:
With a baby monitor using 2.4MHz you have to be close. No way you'll see your kid from the baby monitor if you're at an office and the child is at home. You'll have to get a wireless camera. 
 It's totally the microwaves at lunchtime.

discussion.content: During midday the maids or child carers will always check their babies from the baby monitor which has a bandwidth of 2.4 MHz that causes interference. :)

I believe answer is correct. If there are a loss of DHCP addresses then that would explain why some users are experiencing "loss of connection". Also, if there is an issue with DHCP exhaustion then perhaps we are experiencing a great deal of traffic as tehre are going to be more users throughout mid day, this would explain lack of speeds too.

Perhaps, it is C because as the day goes on, the DHCP runs out of addresses. It just happens around Mid-Day. The answer A may be a red herring. How close is this network to these small appliances that it causes network issues?

comments.content: This is a good explanation for the answer.
but out of address DHCP does not result slow connection speeds

If DHCP runs out of addresses the system will assign an APIPA address, but remember the context, they are experiencing connectivity issues mostly at a specific time of the day. Also the scenario itself doesn't even has to do anything with DHCP.

Remember this are dumps, they are not certified so if you don't have vast knowledge you can trust every answer and fail the exam
The quality of this NETWORK+ questions is very poor but i belive C is correct just because the question states "slow down" (due to congestion) and connectivity issues (DHCP exaustion).

discussion.content: Why is every "interference" question wrong on this site? This could really hurt people that don't know any better!
i agree with A... staff are on lunch.. hence DHCP does not have to issue alot of IPs
I picked up A for the best answer, the other answers are not even making sense to the given scenario. However, i didn't think of using microwave would cause losing connection.

choices.D: The DNS cache on the users' computers has become corrupt
choices.A: There is interference from small appliances
choices.B: The signal coverage area is too small
choices.C: Not enough DHCP addresses have been allotted

comments.content: I think physical also makes the most sense.
If the PC NIC had a problem then the connected IP wouldnt work.

discussion.content: What does it mean by ‘connecting’ ? Do they mean physically or can’t ‘connect’ logically ? This question is BOGUS. What if it’s the NIC card in the PC ? What if it’s the network cable ? The question doesn’t say if the SAME cable is being used ! The answer could in fact be ANY of the OSI Layers as the issue. I’m going with Physical.
I had run into this issue many times and normally it was because the PC had static IP instead of DHCP. An IP related issue should be layer 3, network layer.

comments.content: I agree

discussion.content: My guess was B - Physical. And here is why. IP phones in this scenario have 2 Ports. 1x for wall jack to IP phone and 1x for PC connection. All IP phones seems to work correctly even the users phone. That means the issue is between the IP phone and the PC. In my opinion, cable between PC and IP phone could be the problem.

Assuming "the PC connects to an IP phone, which is working correctly" means the computer can use the IP phone (ie. phone to computer working correctly), then it's a network layer issue. Typical CompTIA: don't test the material, just make people guess about how the how to interpret the question. Were other devices tested with the same cable? They don't say. What's "working correctly," the phone or the connection between the PC and the phone? They don't say. Either network or physical could be correct based on how the question is interpreted. Just ridiculous...

there a few reasons, the network switch port should be configured for VLAN data and VLAN Voice each Vlan gets different DHCP pools assignments switch->phone-->PC if the PC not able to connect, it could be a patch cord issue, VLAN issue, a DHCP issue
I was hoping Takoyaki would provide an insightful response.
I'm not sure I understand "the PC connects to an iPhone"

comments.content: I did the same thing....it's time to go to bed
lmao, I just realized it was IP phone and not iPhone. You can tell Im reviewing late at night, Anyways, thanks man. Appreciate it.

Thats the normal setup for IP phones these days. You hardly see a dedicated port for and IP phone, its connnected through the PC and then subscribe to a voice vlan.
By the way its not an Iphone but an IP phone

I agree, had to reread the question a couple times but the answer is A, when they say "the PC is connected to a IP phone" it's sneaky way to tell us that there's something on the network it can communicate with.

discussion.content: Looks like physical layer but it does not say any cable but the wired network (device). So, network is the issue.
Physical is the correct answer. Other devices are successfully connecting the IP phone which routs VoIP. the problem stays with PC, type of cable which is consider as Physical layer.

comments.content: If it were physical the phone wouldn't work with the PC... That's why they added that bit of information.
Yes, it's most likely a cabling issue

discussion.content: I think the issue is "logical".
Physical connection.

questions.question_text: A user reports difficulties connecting a PC to a wired network. The PC connects to an IP phone, which is working correctly. A network technician can verify that other devices successfully connect to the phone. At which of the following layers of the OSI model is the problem MOST likely located?

comments.content: Nailed it right here, thanks for insight.

discussion.content: I think the reason why C is the correct answer is because a proximity reader will grant access to a user with proximity card that it recognizes. It doesn't need to know if the user is legitimate or not.
I thought biometric devices cause more false positives

comments.content: Me as well, and the proximity reader is a more a technical control
I thought so too.

discussion.content: the key again "MOST likely to be susceptible" Proximity then Biometric, both create false Positives I go with Proximity based on the wording of question

I worked at a Alarm Centre for a few years, Proximity sensors can be tripped by anything from wild life, movement of plants being hit by the wind, cars driving close. Usually those sensors are accompanied by video surveillance and door magnet precisely because of the false positives.

comments.content: but the question states "proximity readers" not "proximity sensors". 2 different things.
They use the same type of technology, what are you on about LOL

discussion.content: One of the issues with biometrics is the occurrence of false positives and false negatives.
Cameras in the right place are precise, biometrics also. An identification can be a true negative and the proximity reader is the false positive. Answer is C.
MOST likely to me would be Cameras because someone could be falsely identified more easily than a proximity reader.

questions.question_text: Which of the following physical security controls is MOST likely to be susceptible to a false positive?

A network technician is deploying mobile phones for a company's sales staff. Salespeople frequently travel nationally and internationally to meet with clients, and often have to roam or switch cellular providers. Which of the following standards is the BEST option to fit the requirements?

comments.content: That's interesting! Thanks for sharing that. I just learned something I didn't know! :)

discussion.content: The Global System for Mobile Communications (GSM) is a standard developed by the European Telecommunications Standards Institute (ETSI) to describe the protocols for second-generation (2G) digital cellular networks used by mobile devices such as mobile phones and tablets. It was first deployed in Finland in December 1991.[2] By the mid-2010s, it became a global standard for mobile communications achieving over 90% market share, and operating in over 193 countries and territories.[3]

From the choices, there are only two that cover phone signal technologies.
GSM - Global System for Mobile Communications (availability in over 210 countries)
CDMA - Code Division Multiple Access (less than 18% of the networks around the world)

https://www.androidauthority.com/gsm-vs-cdma-689328/

Other Technologies / NOT CELL
TDM - Time Division Multiplexing
PSTN - Public Switched Telephone Network
MIMO - Multiple In/Multiple Out

Most mobile system providers use GSM. There are a few exceptions, but if you buy a phone online that is unlocked for the purpose of switching your phone providers service from your current phone to that new phone it will most likely say "GSM" on the title to let you know that phone providers that use the GSM standard can be used on that particular phone.
This was a good eye sight test
